Key Arguments: The Bill poses a significant threat to freedom of speech and privacy.
The ACMA is given excessive powers akin to a court without the same standards of evidence.
The Bill could be weaponized against Australians, causing distress through legal processes.
It undermines freedom of political expression and could harm Australia's international reputation.
The Bill is unnecessary given existing legislation and self-regulatory measures by the private sector.
There are insufficient checks and balances on the powers granted to ACMA and the Minister.
The Bill could lead to self-censorship and chilling effects on free speech.
It poses national security risks by potentially alienating the IT and information security community.
Notable Quotes: The legislation proposed in the Bill will make this a reality.
The Bill, wholly or in part, must never pass, because it is a significant threat to our democracy, freedom of speech, privacy and our national security.
The Bill presents adds to the significant threat to democracy presented by legislation which stifles expression using the threat of retribution or remand.
The proposed legislation is a significant contribution towards cementing Australia amongst oppressive regimes such as North Korea and China.
The government would be best to spend its efforts in fostering healthy and productive cooperation between citizens and officials, by gaining their trust instead of losing it.
